node.title: computation question with moose solver
node.bodyText: Solved
Solved

node.title: Homogenization for non regular and non orthogonal mesh
node.bodyText: I am trying to perform asymptotic homogenization of a periodic structure wherein the unit cell is a rhombus. Is there a way to run the homogenization process using the AsymptoticExpansionHomogenizationKernel?
@jasondhales you're the author of that object
I haven't tried it, but my guess is that as long as you set up the periodic boundary conditions properly, it will work.

Is it possible to change the repeating axes orientation? For example, when defining the periodic BC for a square unit cell, the repeating axes (X and Y) are perpendicular to each other and coincident with the Cartesian plane. However, for a rhombus type unit cell, this wouldn't be case.

node.title: Preconditioners for FE INS simulations
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I've been trying to run INS simulations with various open flow type geometries. For instance, flow around a circular cylinder, or flow over a flat plate.
Using the lu preconditioner, I am able to run simulations even at high Reynolds numbers (I'm wanting to experiment up to around Re~1e6).
However, even at much lower Reynolds numbers, I have been unable to achieve convergence of the linear solves using any preconditioner besides lu.
I am hoping to simulate some large meshes in future and I gather that whilst robust, lu is very memory intensive. Therefore, I would like to have the option to use some other preconditioner better suited to large problems.
Generally speaking, I have seen no difference between steady and transient solves.
For transient solves, I have also tried ramping the viscosity so that the simulation starts with a low Reynolds number, then gradually increasing it with time.
Whilst the residual starts off smaller, the convergence appears to be no better even at the first time step.
Worth mentioning among the options I have tried so far, I noticed that adjusting pc_factor_levels with ilu did not seem to make a difference.
However, from my understanding, the more 'levels of fill' with ilu, the closer its resemblance to lu?
I would therefore expect to see some difference, and wonder if I am misunderstanding something about what ilu is doing.
I have also read through #16113 and tried:
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_asm_overlap -sub_pc_type -sub_pc_factor_levels  -ksp_gmres_restart'
petsc_options_value = 'bjacobi      2               ilu          4       200'

and a few variations, but no avail.
In my related thread #23274, GiudGiud suggests that something involving FSP could be helpful here; however, in #16113, lindsayad mentions that he's found asm and bjacobi to be better for INS problems.
Any advice on where I should look here would be greatly appreciated. Choosing appropriate preconditioners still seems something of a mystery to me at times!
For what it's worth, below is an example input file in case there are other mistakes I'm making!
Thanks!
filename = exampleFile
velocity_x = 5 # 5 for Re=5million at x=1

[Mesh]
    [base]
        type = FileMeshGenerator
        file = ./mesh/FlatPlateMesh_2D.msh
    []
[]

[Variables]
    [velocity]
        family = LAGRANGE_VEC
        block = 'fluid'
    []
    [pressure]
        block = 'fluid'
    []
[]

[ICs]
    [velocity]
        type = VectorConstantIC
        x_value = ${velocity_x}
        y_value = 1e-13
        variable = velocity
    []
[]

[Functions]
    # [mu]                         #Use this to try ramping Re in transient solves
    #     type = ParsedFunction
    #     value = 'if (t <= 0.5, 1.789e-5 - ((t-0.1)*(1.789 - 1.789e-5)/0.1), 1.789e-5)'    #Ramps from 1.7e-2 to 1.7e-5
    # []
    [mu]                           #Fixed mu for SS solves
        type = ParsedFunction
        value = '1.789e-5'
    []
[]

[Materials]
    [fluid] # Air, ISA sea lvl
        type = ADGenericFunctionMaterial
        prop_names = 'rho mu T cp k'
        prop_values = '1.225 mu 288 1005 0.02596'
        block = 'fluid'
    []
    [ins_mat]
        type = INSADStabilized3Eqn
        velocity = velocity
        pressure = pressure
        temperature = '288'
        block = 'fluid'
        alpha = 1.0
    []
[]

[Kernels]
    [mass_conservation]
        type = INSADMass
        variable = pressure
    []
    # [momentum_time]
    #     type = INSADMomentumTimeDerivative
    #     variable = velocity
    # []
    [momentum_advection]
        type = INSADMomentumAdvection
        variable = velocity
    []
    [momentum_pressure]
        type = INSADMomentumPressure
        variable = velocity
        pressure = pressure
    []
    [momentum_viscous]
        type = INSADMomentumViscous
        variable = velocity
    []

    [momentum_supg]
        type = INSADMomentumSUPG
        variable = velocity
        velocity = velocity
    []
    [mass_pspg]
        type = INSADMassPSPG
        variable = pressure
    []
[]

[BCs]
    [inlet]
        type = VectorDirichletBC
        values = '${velocity_x} 0 0'
        variable = velocity
        boundary = 'inlet'
    []
    [outlet]
        type = ADDirichletBC
        value = 0
        variable = pressure
        boundary = 'outlet'
    []
    [free_slip]
        type = ADVectorFunctionDirichletBC
        variable = velocity
        boundary = 'bottom_upstream top'
        function_y = 0
        set_x_comp = False
        set_y_comp = True
        set_z_comp = False
    []
    [no_slip_wall]
        type = VectorDirichletBC
        values = '0 0 0'
        variable = velocity
        boundary = 'plate'
    []
[]

[Preconditioning]
    [precond]
        type = SMP
        full = true
    []
[]

[Executioner]
    type = Steady
    # dt = 0.0025
    # end_time = 1
    solve_type = NEWTON
    nl_rel_tol = 1e-10
    nl_max_its = 35
    l_tol = 1e-10
    l_max_its = 50
    automatic_scaling = true
    line_search = default

    #These petsc options work:
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type'      
    petsc_options_value = 'lu       NONZERO'


    #Uncomment below for transient solves

    # dtmax = 0.0025
    # [TimeStepper]
    #     type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    #     # dt = 1E-5
    #     dt = 0.0001
    #     growth_factor = 1.5
    #     cutback_factor = 0.8
    # []
[]

[Outputs]
    [OutputFile]
        type = Exodus
        file_base = ${filename}
    []
[]
Have you tried field splits?

Not yet, as I believe vector variables are not currently accommodated? However, to use the momentum SUPG kernel, I am required to pass a vector variable for velocity.
I am going to try rewriting the input file with separate variables for u and v, perhaps without SUPG or perhaps using aux variables to convert between vectors and standard variables.
This should enable me to try field split, and I will report back.

We have added more support for field splits with vector variables about two months ago.
AuxVariables for conversions likely wont work. Auxvariables wont keep track of the dependencies of residual terms on variables
What flow regime is this? What s the Reynolds number? You might have to use SUPG

Reynolds number wise, I am going as high as e6 (I will be experimenting with turbulence options when Re is this high), so I suspect SUPG will be needed?
Ah, good to hear - I'll make sure I'm up-to-date. With the new support, are we able to split a vector variable into its constituent components for the field split?
Or would we be treating the vector as one variable, and preconditioning this (ie, all 3 components) in one split, and other variables such as pressure in another?
If the case is the former, I have been struggling to find how to - or indeed, if it is possible to - refer to a specific component of a vector variable from the MOOSE input file.

You will need SUPG
No you wont be able to split vector variables by component. You can take a look at test/tests/preconditioning/fsp/vector-test.i for an example.
Thanks for confirming - I'll try splitting my velocity vector and pressure variables and see if things improve

You can have a look at this PR on the same topic but just finite volume
#22405

@Eilloo This might work for you. Let me know if it speeds up the problem!
[FSP]
    type = FSP
    topsplit = 'all'
    [all]
      splitting = 'mom mass'
      splitting_type = schur
      schur_type = full
      petsc_options_iname = '-pc_fieldsplit_schur_fact_type -pc_fieldsplit_schur_precondition'
      petsc_options_value = 'full selfp '
    []
    [mom]
      vars = 'velocity'
      petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_type -pc_type -sub_pc_type -sub_ksp_type'
      petsc_options_value = ' preonly  asm      jacobi          preonly'
    []
    [mass]
      vars = 'pressure'
      petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_type -pc_type -pc_hypre_type '
      petsc_options_value = ' preonly   hypre  boomeramg'
    []
  []

An update on this: the good news is that I am getting convergence with some field split options:
What I've tried is far from exhaustive, but so far the following basic options are working okay:
splitting_type = multiplicative
and for both pressure, and velocity separately:
-pc-type = ilu
It's not the fastest, taking around 80 linear iterations each nl solve, but it is converging without lu which is progress.
Max, I did try the options suggested above, but this diverged at the first iteration for me.
As for the settings which worked, these are fairly arbitrary currently, and I'm trying to get a better idea of what's actually going on.
The splitting type certainly makes a big difference - 'additive', for instance does not work nearly as well. I haven't found much detail in the docs on what the differences are so this has been trial and error so far...
Many of the suggestions, including Max's above, involve Schur's complement. From what I have read in the Petsc docs, it seems that whilst there are built-in methods, preconditioning of the Schur's complement matrix itself is non-trivial and often problem specific?
Another general observation which I'm not sure I was expecting, is that the convergence is completely different using FSP with, say, both variables preconditioned with ilu, compared to straight ilu with no field split.
Is this because the systems are decoupled in some way? (Perhaps 'decoupled' is the wrong word here - what I'm getting at is that it's hard to picture how two coupled variables are being isolated in separately preconditioned systems)
After looking at the FV bits linked to, I wonder if you can clarify one more thing for me:
What is the SMP preconditioner acting on? The fact we define both the SMP block, then separately some other preconditioners suggestes they operate on different systems, and I'm interested to know roughly what's going on here.

This is the documentation on field splits
https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/PC/PCFIELDSPLIT/
You shoud be able to map additive, multiplicative and Schur to which term in the coupling is being considered.

node.title: Question about using adaptive mesh on Level-Set
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose Team,
I'm trying to use Level Sets module and I have a question about model convergence with "some kind" of mesh refinements through the level set interface.
Please see attached input file for detailed information. Note that, if you disable Adaptivity, the model converge to a correct solution! Or if you disable option #2, and enable option #1, the model will show a correct solution!
Thank you very much for your help,
/ Minh
size = 1
# Option 1: Adaptive mesh over all geometry size. Solution is ok
#asize = ${size}

# Option 2: Adaptive mesh over 1/3 geometry size. Solution is not ok
asize = ${fparse size/3}
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 3
  xmin = 0
  xmax = ${size}
  ymin = 0
  ymax = ${size}
  zmin = 0
  zmax = ${size}
  nx = 10
  ny = 10
  nz = 10
[]

[Variables]
  [./phi]
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./velocity]
    family = LAGRANGE_VEC
  [../]
[]

[ICs]
  [./phi_ic]
    type = FunctionIC
    function = phi_exact
    variable = phi
  [../]
  [./vel_ic]
    type = VectorFunctionIC
    variable = velocity
    function = velocity_func
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [./phi_exact]
    type = LevelSetOlssonPlane
    point = '${fparse size/2} ${fparse size/2} ${fparse size/2}'
    normal = '0 0 1'
    epsilon = ${fparse size/15}
  [../]
  [./velocity_func]
    type = ParsedVectorFunction
    expression_x = '1e-15'
    expression_y = '1e-15'
    expression_z = '1e-15'
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [top]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = phi
    boundary = front
    value = 1
  []
  [bottom]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = phi
    boundary = back
    value = 0
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [./advection]
    type = LevelSetAdvection
    velocity = velocity
    variable = phi
  [../]
  [./advection_supg]
    type = LevelSetAdvectionSUPG
    velocity = velocity
    variable = phi
  [../]
[]

[Adaptivity]
  initial_marker = initial_marker_phi
  initial_steps = 2
  max_h_level = 2
  cycles_per_step = 2
  recompute_markers_during_cycles = true

  marker = initial_marker_phi
  steps = 1

  [Markers]
    [initial_marker_phi]
      type = BoxMarker
      bottom_left = '0 0 ${fparse size/2.5}'
      top_right = '${size} ${asize} ${fparse size/2}'
      inside = refine
      outside = do_nothing
    []
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-3
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-7
  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist'
[]

[Outputs]
  csv = true
  exodus = true
[]

Correct solution

Wrong solution
Are these results converged? Can you paste the execution log for the second case

Framework Information:
MOOSE Version:           git commit 9721739139 on 2023-01-25
LibMesh Version:         a476dcb36d78923b9d2ed13b937b388f00da77f4
PETSc Version:           3.16.6
SLEPc Version:           3.16.2
Current Time:            Mon Jan 30 21:29:49 2023
Executable Timestamp:    Tue Jan 24 13:56:40 2023

Parallelism:
  Num Processors:          1
  Num Threads:             1

Mesh: 
  Parallel Type:           replicated
  Mesh Dimension:          3
  Spatial Dimension:       3
  Nodes:                   1331
  Elems:                   1000
  Num Subdomains:          1

Nonlinear System:
  Num DOFs:                1331
  Num Local DOFs:          1331
  Variables:               "phi" 
  Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE" 
  Approximation Orders:    "FIRST" 

Auxiliary System:
  Num DOFs:                4993
  Num Local DOFs:          4993
  Variables:               "velocity" "initial_marker_phi" 
  Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE_VEC" "MONOMIAL" 
  Approximation Orders:    "FIRST" "CONSTANT" 

Execution Information:
  Executioner:             Steady
  Solver Mode:             NEWTON
  MOOSE Preconditioner:    SMP (auto)

 0 Nonlinear |R| = 1.662917e-01
      0 Linear |R| = 1.662917e-01
      1 Linear |R| = 4.558296e-13
 1 Nonlinear |R| = 4.197392e-13
 Solve Converged!
Mesh unchanged, skipping remaining steps...
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 2.624513e-19
 Solve Converged!
Seems to be well converging, much below the tolerances set
Any update on this?

No,
I still can not simulate a steady-state of a level-set problem with a different mesh size (adaptive mesh level) over the level-set interface.

ok thanks for the update.
At this point I think this is because the problem is ill-posed.
You have Dirichlet BCs on both sides yet are advecting from one face to the other. What do you think the steady state would look like?
How does phi go from 1 to 0 with just an advection (with a fixed velocity) process

Thanks @GiudGiud !
My problem occurs in the first stage of the simulation, when the velocity is very small. And it worked for me with the above BC diriclet, for a simple mesh (option #1).
By removing the BCs, I got a convergence for option #2, but it converged to a linear solution. Do you think it would be better using re-initialization?

If the system is ill-posed the solution will depend on the mesh but is not really to be trusted.
Linear seems odd as well.
Dont you expect the value to just propagate through the entire mesh from the dirichlet BC?

I just expected, with a very small velocity, it should not convect the level-set, but it seems doesn't work for me, for the Steady state solver. Now I am testing my problem on a Transient system instead.
Thank you very much!

Transient seems like a good idea.
In steady even a tiny velocity will be able to advect across the domain, the timestep is essentially 'infinite'

nl_rel_tol = 1e-3
nl_abs_tol = 1e-7
this seems much too loose.
You need to tighten both

Yes, I will.
This is just for testing

node.title: timestep_limiting_postprocessor settings
node.bodyText:
I am trying to implement an adaptive time stepping scheme based on the change of value of one or more of my internal state variables (AuxVariables). I looked up the manual and it says that the option timestep_limiting_processor enables one to specify a list of postprocessor values used as an upper limit for the current time step length. I am very much confused by this without further examples. Suppose I want to make sure that the time step size is such that the variable xalpha does not change by more than 10^-3 over a time step. Should the corresponding specification be something like the following?
[Executioner]
   ...
    [TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 1.0e2
    optimal_iterations = 20
    iteration_window = 10
    linear_iteration_ratio = 100
    force_step_every_function_point = true
    timestep_limiting_postprocessor = dt_pp
  []
[]
...
[Postprocessor]
  [xalpha]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = xalpha
    use_displaced_mesh = false
  []
  [dxalpha]
    type = ChangeOverTimePostprocessor
    postprocessor = xalpha
  []
  [dt]
    type = TimestepSize
  []
  [dt_pp]
    type = ParsedPostprocessor
    constant_names = target_delta
    constant_expressions = 1e-3
    pp_names = 'dt dxalpha xalpha'
    function = 'dt*target_delta/dxalpha'
  []
[]

Also, I tried to play around with options. I notice that with a setting of dtmin = 1 and dtmax = 1e6, whenever I have this postprocessor on, the time step size would drop to dtmin = 1, then double until it reaches 64, and drops all the way to 1 again, repeating itself. For my problem at hand this will be exceedingly slow. I wonder if there's any way to rectify this and not have it reset to dtmin whenever I need it to decrease? Thank you.

Hello
So if the auxvariable changes more than 1e-3 over a timestep, what do you want to do?
Restart the time step or accept it but diminish the timestep size for the next one?
The doubling and cutting of the IterationAdaptiveDT is tied to the number of non linear iterations. There's a window where the dt is constant, and if the solver takes more than N + window_size non linear iterations, the time step decreases.
Similarly, if the solver takes less than N-window_size NL iterations to converge, the time step increases
Guillaume

I would think that the most prudent course of action, if the AuxVariable changes too much, would be to restart the time step, halve the step size, but not decrease it all the way to dtmin.
Are there other settings (e.g., number of linear and/or nonlinear iterations) that I need to make?
Thank you.

Unfortunately I dont think we have this kind of behavior available.
This is likely the closest thing to be able to accept or reject time steps, but it will need to be adapted, it s not very close.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/timesteppers/AB2PredictorCorrector.html
In fact the actual closest one that used to be able to accept/reject after the fact got removed
#21576
@loganharbour is DT2 still functional if we bring it back locally? The OP could just host it in their own app since they want something similar

Unfortunately I dont think we have this kind of behavior available.
This is likely the closest thing to be able to accept or reject time steps, but it will need to be adapted, it s not very close. https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/timesteppers/AB2PredictorCorrector.html
In fact the actual closest one that used to be able to accept/reject after the fact got removed #21576

This is interesting. I had used IterationAdaptiveDT before, but with timestep_limiting_function and without timestep_limiting_postprocessor. I was under the impression that IterationAdaptiveDT, at least with the timestep_limiting_function option, would cut the time step size by half by default, instead of dropping it all the way to dtmin?

Yes it can cut the timestep by half.
However it accepts the solution before doing so. If you want to reject the solution then try again, this was removed with DT2

it must be that the value does not change after the timestep is cut. So it keep cutting ?
Could you please attach the log?

There is no log file (is there a way to generate one?), but I append the screen output at the step when dt drops from 64 to 1. From this point on dt may double all the way to 64 before dropping to 1 at the subsequent step.
Time Step 34, time = 315905, dt = 64
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 1.492114e+00
    |residual|_2 of individual variables:
                     disp_x: 1.48325
                     disp_y: 0.162427
                     temp:   0.00148177
   Solution, reference convergence variable norms:
   disp_x: 1.48325  disp_x_ref: 12496.5
   disp_y: 0.162427  disp_y_ref: 2865.53
   temp:   0.00148177  temp_ref:   416.708
      0 Linear |R| = 1.492114e+00
      1 Linear |R| = 8.848718e-01
      2 Linear |R| = 1.571879e-01
 1 Nonlinear |R| = 1.571848e-01
    |residual|_2 of individual variables:
                     disp_x: 0.10502
                     disp_y: 0.116952
                     temp:   0.000341083
   Solution, reference convergence variable norms:
   disp_x: 0.10502  disp_x_ref: 12495.8
   disp_y: 0.116952  disp_y_ref: 2865.51
   temp:   0.000341083  temp_ref:   416.709
 Solve Converged!

...

Time Step 35, time = 315906, dt = 1
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 1.586037e-01
    |residual|_2 of individual variables:
                     disp_x: 0.106828
                     disp_y: 0.11723
                     temp:   0.000349773
   Solution, reference convergence variable norms:
   disp_x: 0.106828  disp_x_ref: 12495.8
   disp_y: 0.11723  disp_y_ref: 2865.51
   temp:   0.000349773  temp_ref:   416.709
 Solve Converged!

I presume the postprocessor values are not of interest...

Actually all of that is of interest.
Could you please attach the full console output, with the postprocessor values

By the way here I used, in my postprocessor,
  [dt_pp]
    type = ParsedPostprocessor
    constant_names = target_delta
    constant_expressions = 2e-1
    pp_names = 'dt dxalpha xalpha'
    function = 'dt*target_delta/(dxalpha/xalpha)'
  []

I played with other expressions for function and values for target_delta and I end up with the same situation of dt dropping all the way to 1 and then increasing until it maxes out at 64 and drops again cyclically.

node.title: Cannot open VcXsrv (Peacock) Windows 11
node.bodyText: I have recently downloaded MOOSE using the Windows 10 instructions, however, I am technically on Windows 11. I am unable to display VcXsrv to use peacock but I can run the examples provided in moose. I have ran through the downloading steps again to ensure I did not miss a step. Does anyone have any advice?

Hello
Did you do everything in the documentation:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/windows.html#f21a2a8e-8f48-4c31-bc33-f52b73e4f1a4

Launched VcXsrv before WSL
Disabled access control
Allowed network connections VcXsrv
Guillaume

Windows 11 provides native GL support. There is no need to install VcXsrv (Ref a recent discussion: #22718 (reply in thread)). None of us here have a Windows 11 machine to test on, this was something I discovered via Microsoft's help topics).
However, you may still find some useful information within that post...

node.title: mpi_init() not found
node.bodyText:
Hi, im using cardinal to install MOOSE, and when I try to install PETSc by running this line in cardinal './contrib/moose/scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh', I get the following error:

I have installed mpi using mpich, and cannot see what the problem could be.
Any help would be appreciated

In the future please do not post screenshots of text, paste the text instead. Otherwise your post would not be searchable by its contents.
Can you please share what install process you used for mpich? Our preferred method in this case would be use conda (see here) with the moose-mpich package for a mpich environment that is tested rigorously by us.
It is significantly more difficult for us to support environment installations that are not covered in our instructions.

Hi,
Apologies I will use that in the future. I used the mpich installation guide outlined here: https://www.mpich.org/static/downloads/4.1/mpich-4.1-README.txt. However the problem was that I was missing a line in my bashrc file so this problem has now been fixed. I cannot use a conda environment due to conflicts with NekRS which I intend to use later.
I now have run into the following problem, these are the last few lines of the console output:
================================================================================      Configuring PARMETIS with cmake; this may take several minutes            ================================================================================================================================================================      Compiling and installing PARMETIS; this may take several minutes          ================================================================================TESTING: configureLibrary from config.packages.hdf5(config/BuildSystem/config/pa*******************************************************************************
         UNABLE to CONFIGURE with GIVEN OPTIONS    (see configure.log for details):
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--with-hdf5-dir=/home/ryan/.local/share/Trash/files/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/src/binding/petsc4py/src/include did not work
*******************************************************************************

There was an error. Exiting...   

The last few lines of the configure.log file are:

*******************************************************************************
         UNABLE to CONFIGURE with GIVEN OPTIONS    (see configure.log for details):
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--with-hdf5-dir=/home/ryan/.local/share/Trash/files/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/src/binding/petsc4py/src/include did not work
*******************************************************************************
  File "/home/ryan/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/config/configure.py", line 467, in petsc_configure
    framework.configure(out = sys.stdout)
  File "/home/ryan/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/config/BuildSystem/config/framework.py", line 1389, in configure
    self.processChildren()
  File "/home/ryan/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/config/BuildSystem/config/framework.py", line 1377, in processChildren
    self.serialEvaluation(self.childGraph)
  File "/home/ryan/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/config/BuildSystem/config/framework.py", line 1352, in serialEvaluation
    child.configure()
  File "/home/ryan/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/config/BuildSystem/config/package.py", line 1191, in configure
    self.executeTest(self.configureLibrary)
  File "/home/ryan/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/config/BuildSystem/config/base.py", line 138, in executeTest
    ret = test(*args,**kargs)
  File "/home/ryan/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/config/BuildSystem/config/packages/hdf5.py", line 94, in configureLibrary
    config.package.GNUPackage.configureLibrary(self)
  File "/home/ryan/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/config/BuildSystem/config/package.py", line 937, in configureLibrary
    for location, directory, lib, incl in self.generateGuesses():
  File "/home/ryan/cardinal/contrib/moose/petsc/config/BuildSystem/config/package.py", line 566, in generateGuesses
    raise RuntimeError('--with-'+self.package+'-dir='+self.argDB['with-'+self.package+'-dir']+' did not work')
================================================================================
Finishing configure run at Thu, 02 Feb 2023 15:23:08 +0000
================================================================================


I understand if this is not the correct forum for this, however I have been directed here from cardinal. Thanks in advance

Hello
Can you attach the config.log file and the moose/scripts/diagnostic output
Guillaume

Ive attached both config.log and configure.log just incase you meant configure.log, thanks in advance

What machine are you running on? this isnt enough to build moose, and petsc probably (I dont know)

Im using a virtual machine that has 5024 mb allocated to it. My host machine only has 8gb but ill try and allocate it an extra gb and close down any processes using memory. Ive rerun that script and its saying 2300 mb now. Is 5024mb enough?

https://mooseframework.inl.gov/sqa/minimum_requirements.html
on paper we need the full 8 Gb.
In practice you may be able to wing it.
when you compile, use -j 1 everywhere to limit the memory consumption. It will take forever though
Well thats not ideal. Thank you for your help, hopefully i'll be able to find a fix.
Something else to be sure about; I see both MPICH and OpenMPI available within your PATH. Sometimes things afoul can occur due to this.

node.title: Issue in using Volumetric EigenStrain module
node.bodyText:
Hello Moose Experts, I am trying to use ComputeVolumetricEigenstrain as follows for axisymmetric (RZ) problem.
[./volumetric_eigenstrain]
    type = ComputeVolumetricEigenstrain
    volumetric_materials = volumetric_change
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain
    args = ''
    block = 'silicon'
[../]

  [./volumetric_change]
    type = GenericFunctionMaterial
    prop_names = volumetric_change
    prop_values = 't'
    block = 'silicon'
  [../]

in which t is end time of the simulation which I am using as t=2. However, when I am trying to extract the volume of the mesh block using VolumePostProcessor, I am getting V/V_0=2.6621. Can you please help me to understand why this value is more than 2 when my input value is 2.
I am also calculating the volumetric_strain using following module:
  [./volumetric_strain]
    type = RankTwoScalarAux
    scalar_type = VolumetricStrain
    rank_two_tensor = total_strain
    variable = volumetric_strain
  [../]

and with this total volumetric strain I am getting is 1.91. I also wonder why this value is less than 2.
Thank you very much.
Best,
Avtar

Update:
I found out that I need to subtract 1 from the volume ratio.
So, 2.6621-1 = 1.6621
But the volumetric strain I am getting is 1.91.
I have tried with fine mesh as well but the changes are at the second digit level.
Best,
Avtar

In which number of dimensions is this?
The volume does not scale linearly if the system is expanding in all directions

Hello Guillaume,
This is in axis-symmetric problem (RZ-direction).
Best,
Avtar
I think you ll need to double check the analytical formula. Expansion is Z causes a linear expansion in volume but in R it s quadratic with a Pi factor in there

node.title: How to record historical maximum value?
node.bodyText: I use a custom AuxKernel to help calculate the strain energy in an uni-axial loading simulation. I also need to record the maximum historical strain energy of each node, but I have no idea how to do that. Could anyone please give me some advice?

Use a ElementExtremeValue to get the max on every time step
then use a ParsedPostprocessor to perform the max operation between the previous value (saved in the parsed one) and the current max
Guillaume

node.title: Welcome to MOOSE Discussions!
node.bodyText:
Welcome!
We are exploring the use of Discussions as place to connect with other members of the MOOSE community. We hope that you:

Ask questions.
Share ideas.
Engage with other MOOSE users and developers.

To get started, comment below with an introduction of yourself and tell us about what you doing with MOOSE.
We are just testing this out, but I believe this may be a replacement (or at least an alternative) to the mailing list.
I am Som. My background is in uncertainty quantification. I am currently developing a fluid-structure interaction module in MOOSE.
@aeslaughter, where's your intro?

I am Andrew and have been a MOOSE developer since 2013. My academic background is in engineering mechanics. Within MOOSE I have all sorts of jobs, including leading the stochastic tools module development.

I've been working with the MOOSE team for about a year now, and have been using MOOSE for the last four years. My primary research interest is radiation transport, but I've also been working recently on general framework development as well.
I'm gonna play around with this answered thing real quick...
I am replying, to see what that looks like.
Hello there!
...man I really like the threading versus doing this over a standard e-mail list.
The ability to easily reference discussion numbers in issues and PRs and visa versa seems amazing. I could easily see this replacing the mailing list
How hard to search for a topic on the platform?

Hi, I'm Cody and I'm currently managing the Computational Frameworks team at the Idaho National Laboratory who maintain MOOSE. I'm always looking for new collaborative opportunities to get this framework into the community.

Hi, I'm Casey! I've been working with the MOOSE team for about 2.5 years now, and have been using MOOSE for around the last 4-5 years. My research is focused on electromagnetics and low temperature plasma physics modeling and simulation (with some fusion work here and there). I also do occasional MOOSE framework and module development.
I locked the discussion, but "Collaborators" still have the power.
What exactly does discussion locking do?  Does it prevent everyone from adding new posts.  Does it prevent replies?  Does it only affect non-collaborators? etc.
Locking prevents everyone who doesn't have write access to MOOSE from making new comments.
Should we announce this forum on moose-users?
I’d say post that we’re considering using it more and welcome questions here as well. With a note that we’re not switching yet, we would just like some use here so we can gauge if we like it or not.
I agree - also, the more feedback we can send up based on user engagement to possibly improve it more to our liking, the better
I'm just not sure how many simultaneous places I can pay attention.  groups, slack, teams, email, github discussions, tiny-town (or whatever), etc.

I hope this replaces the mailing list and helps with this problem. I am using github.com/notifications which would include posts to the discussions. If we switch it would actually eliminate one place you need to pay attention to.

I agree.  I know we had contemplated a discourse/discord sort of thing also.  I guess I'm just advocating for keeping the intermediate timeframe where we simultaneously have multiple platforms being used down to a minimum (i.e. short evaluation/transition period).  This would indeed be an improvement - I often forget about the mailing list because I'm just busy other places like github.

I hope we're not hemorrhaging too many users with the switch. Also this support channel requires users to sign up for a new service (whereas pretty much everyone already has email).
I'm curious as to what you think the advantages of this over email are? I like the "accepted answer"  feature, although it is not always applicable in our threads, where answers from multiple people can be complementary or incremental.

I suspect integration with github issues/PRs will also be nice.  Plus many of the devs are already spending time perusing github - it will be easier for us (at least for me) to engage more regularly I think.  But - needing a github account is a pretty big downside :-/

I think the threaded conversation is the main advantage with accepted answers being another nice feature. But, I also like the idea of having all MOOSE activity in one location. It will be easier to link to issues, etc.
No offline support either.
Is that really an issue?

Testing email reply.
…
On Wed, Aug 26, 2020 at 4:43 PM Alex Lindsay ***@***.***> wrote:
 Also, perhaps unlikely, but maybe a greater chance that users put their
 code on github... It would be pretty awesome to link directly to issues/PRs
 on their own repository from a MOOSE discussion

 —
 You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
 Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
 <#15774 (reply in thread)>,
 or unsubscribe
 <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AACTKVNYW7RWOIXPQCSJLH3SCWF2RANCNFSM4QFNG7IA>
 .
